description: My friends and I was not expecting this.   Live music and singing.  The waitress service was excellent and was very attentative to us.   Then a guy from a table next to us refilled our nacho for us and ask if we like our Sangria refilled?   I think maybe he works there or he's the manager or the owner?    Our lunch here was a great experience today on a Easter sunday.
author: Tony W.

description: I love this place! They had the best food, ambiance, music, etc. Whenever I'm in the Mission and craving Mexican food this is my to go place. Although there are numerous taqueria's around, I decide to go to La Corneta because whenever I'm there I just feel like I'm in Mexico or something. The painting of Virgin Mary stares down at me while I'm savoring my super taco. There's also live music. Who doesn't love live music? I can't even get started on how yummy the food is. Give this place a try, you won't regret it!
author: Stefany Z.

description:
I love coming here and if I'm in the mood fro Mexican food and I'm in the Mission this is the place we head to. 
I either get a carne asada super burrito or the super nachos, which is an amazing dome of food. 
My friends and I usually come here before heading to the bars. There's always a table (even if it looks full, remember there are tables in the back you can't see from the door) and they have beer and wine if you want. 
Great place for chilling with the guys and getting full on some good Mexican food.
author: Ivana T.

description: I used to really like La Corneta, but the last few meals there haven't been anything special.  They do have a big menu and plenty of seating, so it's good for groups.
author: Bud L.

description: I always get the Super Baby Shrimp and Steak Burrito.  Great price and fills me up.  Its always nice to be able to see how clean the food stations are and how clean the grill is.  The Verde sauce is great too!
author: Thomas L.

description: I'm really bummed to write a negative review, but I just had what was most likely the worst burrito in over 30 years of living in SF.  The carnitas super was hastily prepared on a busy Sat afternoon, the pork tasted old, and I had to tell the help she forgot the salsa, who then slung a tiny bit in the middle.  The meat was mushy and grey, the black beans tasted like old lard.  For ten bucks I got a wrap that had the texture of and tasted like mashed potatoes made with lard.  To make matters worse, my burrito had a large whole bay leaf in it.  What happened, La Corneta?? You were the gold standard when you expanded from the Glen Park location a few years ago.  Ugh, really gross food today, wouldn't feed it to a stray dog.  Too much good competition in the Mission and even the outlying neighborhoods, even snooty Noe Valley.  Will not be coming back!
author: Paul H.

description: Overpriced,everyone that works there has an attitude, and Im suffering from food poisoning from this place.
author: Anthony S.

description:
A great place to grab some cheap eats in the Mission.  I highly recommend the tacos over the burritos.  This is not a burrito place.  It's a taco place.  If you want burritos go to Taqueria Cancun instead.

It's very clean, not a dive at all and more like a restaurant.  There are always musicians playing when I come in and even though there may be a long line they are very efficient.

Tacos are huge.  I get the normal one for like $4 or something and it's enough for lunch.  In fact, it's more like a salad because I can never pick it up and eat it.  You get corn tortillas on the bottom with your choice of meat, beans, lettuce, tomatoes, etc until it's a huge mound on the plate.  All the food is very fresh and yummy.
author: Jean K.

description:
Shut up and go here! This place is the bomb! Such tasty food and such great service and it's just perfect. It's clean and the food on offer is so fresh and tasty, and assembled wtith more than just a 'good enuf' attitude. And those baby burritos....worth all the ab  work...and sooo tasty.
Come here, be well fed, leave happy. 
Enjoy.
author: William M.

description: Great food, but the location on mission St. has a terrible set up. You give the attendant your order and they don't make it in front of you and they get it wrong a lot. Really slow service. Not wild about returning even though the food is delicious. They need to rethink the setup, do it more like Chipotle does.
author: Kay C.

description:
I was dying for a burrito, and so I picked a place with a line going out the door.

La Corneta is a colorful and clean taqueria with ample seating fit for groups. You order at the counter and pay as soon as you step in. You can see everything that's going on in the production including the grill. These people work faaast for how many customers they have.

I got a standard super burrito. They give you chips and salsa that happen to be average, yet I'm so glad they gave me it while I waited. The burrito is fine. It's in between good and average. There are red and green sauces in clear ketchup-like bottles. The sauces are okay but I must warn you about them. If the spout is clogged up and you try to squeeze the sauce it, it will totally explode on your ass. Luckily I have a sense of humor and I laughed it off.

___

Definitely a better burrito place in SF, but if you're in the area and with a couple of friends this'll do.
author: Michael H.

description:
I relied on Yelp while walking down Mission Street to find a good Mexican quick eat. Stopped in front of this restaurant and looked inside. It was a really clean place for the most part, which made me continue to read the reviews. I decided to just try this place rather than continue walking in the darn sun for a good deal. The highlights of Yelpers was the super burrito so I got that with steak, refried beans, and mild salsa. For $8.49, it was an okay burrito. I've had better and my chips didn't come with salsa while my friend who ordered the exact same thing did. The seating area is huge for a taqueria on Mission. Definitely enjoyed the live music and the sunlight from the high ceilings. 

The burrito tasted alright but the steak was not the texture that I know and love. Next time, I'll go with pork. I wasn't full after one whole super burrito. Not sure if that is a good thing. But I finished the other half of my friends to get me to stomach capacity. 

The restrooms are a bit cramped with one toilet in the mens' room and one urinal (sorry for those about to eat or are eating). Paper towels are really thick but that doesn't really matter for hand-washing purposes. I wish they had some highlight specials, or I need to be notified of them.
author: Dominic T.

description: The burrito I ordered was big, meaty, and juicy just the way I like it. And did I mention it's cheap?
author: Daryl R.

description:
You can get a decent vegetarian taco here for under $3.50.  The chips are pretty good and are included with your meal.  The restaurant is large and tables are almost always readily available.

I've been frequenting this place for years and I'd give this place more stars if not for the crappy customer service. This is not a place where you enter the restaurant,  sit down and someone comes and takes your order.  Like many taquerias in the Mission, you wait in line and tell the server behind the counter what you want to order and watch as they put your meal together.  You then pay at the end of the counter and take your food to a table, sit down and eat (unless you've ordered it to go).

I always dread the ordering process here.  The servers always seem to be cranky and impatient.  I always get the impression that they hate their jobs.  And while I can understand wanting to hurry the line along, they could be nicer to their customers.  Because of this, I rarely frequent this establishment anymore. La Corneta could benefit greatly from some customer service training.

A better alternative to La Corneta is El Farolito, a half block away on Mission towards 24th Street.  With the exception of their chips  (which are bland and cost an extra .50), the food and service are far superior at El Farolito.
author: Magnus' D.

description:
I used these guys to cater my birthday party: a taco bar for 60 people.  They were very easy to deal with, reasonably priced, and very professional.  

The food was delivered right on time and piping hot.  I ordered carne asada, al pastor, chicken and vegetable taco fillings and everyone loved it.
author: Vince D.

description: I love this place! I get great service and great food here! Great value for the price! Great atmosphere! I make it a regular dining place.
author: Cathy P.

description: This place was my go to burrito spot a while back. That's mostly what I get here is a super vegetarian burrito. However recently the burritos taste like they don't add enough love into them, seriously though a lot of the time I would be missing guacamole or sour cream and a few times I would just get beans rice and cheese. Now, this kind of sucks already but also sometimes it would have a stale taste to me. Still, burritos aren't the only thing they do. They also serve entrees like sauteed shrimp with mushrooms. These are great, I only wish they didn't add two huge sides of lettuce and refried beans and more shrimp or mushrooms instead. This place is good but not my go-to anymore. Definitely a good place to go and the mariachi music on fridays is nice if your into that.
author: Dan B.

description: By far, the cleanest taqueria in the city (I mean real taquerias, not those americanized Chevy-style shit-holes). But other than that, very very average. Not the biggest, nor the tastiest burrittos, tacos, or other dishes. Very bland meats, beans, sauces, etc. Fresh veggies, but that's the only plus in terms of the food. That, and at least you'll know you're getting some "clean" food. Good place for real mexican food, but so many better places near by.
author: Ron Z.

description: My go-to place for burritos in the Mission. My whole family and I have lived in the mission for over 20 years and we have tried A LOT of taquerias. We have seen them have their ups and downs and right now my current favorite is La Corneta. They have a large selection of food and drink and a giant dining room so you can actually sit down and eat! The staff are all polite, they are very quick and not to mention the food is delicious. I love their baby steak and prawn burrito. They don't skimp on the meat and the food is always well seasoned and generously portioned. Their chips and salsa are pretty standard but I do love their agua fresca. If you want a good burrito for a good price, can't beat this place.
author: Tab C.

description:
I came here for one reason: menudo.
So, I ordered menudo and one carne asada crispy taco.

The menudo was good!  It was full of tripe, which was plentiful and cut bite sized.  As usual, it came with tortillas, onions, oregano, peppers, and limes.  There was a bonus. It comes with tiny cheese quesedilla in corn tortillas!  Yummy!!  And, while I waited, I munched on some tasty chips and salsa.  I'll be back!
author: Jack R.

description:
La Cornets is the mother truckin' BOMB! This is where I take out of town guests to experience 'real' Mission burritos. The super burritos are the size of a baby's arm. 

So tasty.
author: kristin v.

description: I've ordered a combination plate with prawns/beef/chicken. for a $13 meal,  a 200lbs. man can't even finish the whole thing and more important thing is "it's delicious and tasty"    fast cooking chef and waitresses are very friendly compared to another taqueria within the neighbourhood, highly recommend this "huge"little place
author: Jorge H.
Landy G.

description:
La Corneta is my favorite taqueria in San Francisco.  Hell, it may be my favorite restaurant in San Francisco.  I have to restrict myself to ONLY eating here ONCE a week, because if I didn't, I might be here every night.

Their food is always extremely fresh tasting.  I am one of those people who special orders everything, and I really never feel like I'm being a pain.  The way their order process works, it's accomodating to someone like me.

My favorite meal, even though it's horribly cliche is the super steak and prawn nachos.  It used to be the spicy prawn dinner, but I didn't always get the same level of spicy sauce.  When it was good, it was great, but when they didn't get quite enough of the sauce, it was still good, but it didn't send me over the moon.
author: Janet V.

description: Sometimes the food is good but sometimes they do it  so fast and is not good. About people working there are rude.  I get mad because I paid for my food is not free .... RUDE
author: Yessica V.

description:
I've been coming here for years. If there is one clean taqueria you want to bring your friends in the Mission, this is the place. They have a beautiful mural of an angel blowing a trumpet (gabriel) out front and inside there is a huge mural of the virgin mary (guadalupe) lit naturally by the skylights. 

I ordered their combo #2 (cheese quesadilla, shrimp with mushroom, and carne asada taco -- you can choose your own meat or vege option). Very filling and you can split with another person. Good value and courteous order takers, servers. i like the burrito better at el farolito (24th) or la taqueria (19th), so I would skip the burrito when you are there.
author: Sun K.

description:
This place was sooo good! I really enjoyed my dish and so did the others. I sampled everyone else's food and were equally delicious! The big plus, it is a very clean restaurant! 

I will come back for sure!
author: Bernice C.

description:
I came here at around early-dinner hour (6pm) and there was a line, which I thought would be a great indicator of good food. The place is is pretty big and very clean, and the decorations are a bit more modern/new than other joints. However, some of the employees could be a bit nicer. My dialogue while ordering went a little like this:

Me: A chicken super burrito, please
Waitress: What kind of meat?
Me: ...chicken? 

I was ordering for my brother, who was a newbie at this, so I helped him order:

Me: You know my burrito order? Could you add a pork one with everything the same as my other one?
Waitress: Carnitas?
Me (unsure if that is what I wanted) : umm.. yeah. But don't cancel the first one
Waitess: One carnitas? 
*crosses out first one* so no chicken?
Me: No, a total of two
Waitress: *rolls eyes and sighs* 

I was okay with that, because I've seen much worse service, so I shrugged it off as long as she understood in the end. 

I do give a thumbs up for how you can see them making it while you're waiting in line to pay, ensuring cleanliness. 

The manager was quite nice, though, and ensured we all got what we ordered exactly, however we stood there about 5 minutes after paying and getting our food for our chips and salsa and it never came until we asked again. 

All of that was okay with me, but the food (of course) was the biggest gripe. I bit into my burrito, which was slightly smaller than average (I could finish it with no problem), was half cold.
In addition, the rice they use in their burritos contain frozen peas and carrot chunks, which reminds me of cheap Chinese fried rice.

Next time, I'll go to a taqueria where I don't feel like I'm eating Panda Express and at least have the bare necessity of at least luke warm food.
author: Diana S.

description:
Delicious!
Very clean Mexican dishes. Although I can handle some grilled chicken burritos (no rice), I love the Grilled salmons.
author: Anthony M.

description:
Good food. Hard to decide tho because there are 8 others just like it but less expensive. 

Nice location tho. I would take a date there for sure!
author: Dan R.

description:
This is my favorite taqueria in the city! They are clean and provide good customer service . 

Pretty much anything on the menu is good but I would recommend the enchilladas, their chicken or steak dinner plates and any burrito on the menu is excellent!
author: Emilio P.

description:
11/19/09
I had chicken mole enchiladas. Chris had a steak and prawn quesadila. chips and salsa too. shared a churro. total $20. great Mexican food. large portions. we were stuffed! I've had better mole in NYC but this one was pretty close. Cafeteria style. was easy to find. short walk from BART.
author: Liza M.

description: Heard about the baby burritos on here. I wanted to try it out because i can never finish a regular burrito. I really liked this place. Got the super baby chicken burrito. It was flavorful and bigger than I thought. The sangria is tasty as well. IT was clean and suprisingly full.
author: Ayana K.

description:
This is one of my favorite taquerias in San Francisco...not too mention it's in the Mission District.  With all the taquerias in the Mission, this ranks up there.  When I'm craving for a good burrito that's near my work place, I don't have too look too far.  The restaurant is well lit and there's plenty of seating.  It's larger than your typical taqueria. 

Pros: choose from corn, flour, whole wheat, or spinach tortillas; baby burritos; good horchata drink; BofA ATM nearby (I had to add that b/c I seem to always have no cash on me when I'm craving a burrito.)

Cons:  no salsa bar

Also try the 2834 Diamond St. location.  It's just as good.
author: Ricky M.

description:
The Mission District has a lot of great Mexican food but I think this place is a cut above the pack.  I was walking around the Mission asking locals where I should go for really good Mexican food and I had numerous responses point me in the direction of La Corneta.  I'm glad they did.

I got a Super Burrito which was amazing.  My friend got the #4 combo which was equally amazing.  It wasn't the best Mexican I've ever had but for the price and the amount of food you get you can't beat the quality.  

If you're ever in the Mission District stop in to La Corneta.  I think you'll thank me.  

Side note:  A lot of people also suggested El Farolito.  I'm going back to check that place out later.  Stay tuned for the side by side comparison.
author: Tanner M.

description:
Soooo good!  The place is clean. Food is excellent. Big, In a shitty neighborhood, but arent all the best taquerias?? lol.  

Really tho, I ordered a chicken quesidilla and my bf ordered a carnitas burrito. They were soooo good and the portions were huge!

They also had a mariachi band playing! Even tho I dont listen to that kind of music, I thought it was a nice lil touch!
author: BoomBoomBaby Y.

description:
I love the option of the super BABY burrito, grilled chicken, with black beans on a spinach tortilla. I love the super quesadilla. I love love loves the super nachos. 

This place has so many memories for me. My dentist is within the area.  I always get a cleaning.  Mess it up by eating one nice juicy burrito.
author: Val B.

description:
Very tasty food...

And extremely clean as well, which can't be said for the vast majority of Mission esablishments...
author: Nathan W.

description: Food was very good and the service was easy.  I had carnita tacos, prefer hard shells which they didn't have, still it was delicious.   I'd do it again
author: Jo A.

description:
After sampling the excellent cuisine over at the Glen Park location, I was a bit disappointed with the Mission location.

At my last adventure at the GP location, I loved my friends carne asada platter so I decided to get it in the super burrito. I am not sure if they use different meat but this place's carne asada was tough and lacked flavor. The burrito was a bit soupy with too much salsa. There was also peas and carrots in the rice which I hate.

On a positive side, the place it's self is probably the cleanest taqueria in the mission. Much more spread out than El Farlito. Also they have excellent strawberry aqua fesca and delicious salsa.

I would probably take the extra 5 mins on BART and go to the GP location.
author: Jeff P.

description:
I've had more meals from La Corneta than any other restaurant since moving to the mission a few months ago.  At least 10 meals.  Why?  Besides the fact that I'm lazy and don't want to cook, La Corneta is very consistent and the food is good.  Yes, I'm all about consistency.  

I went in with a group of friends a month ago and surprisingly, they have a sit down menu.  I didnt know that.  There was six of us on a Sunday night, and yes we were buzzin'.  The lady working there with the blond hair was SO sweet!  The best customer service and hospitality I've had here in SF.  She was inviting and attentive and funny and just sweet.  My Latino friends from Sacramento want to come down again just to see her.  Though I generally can understand spanish, I caught myself just nodding and smiling a lot when my friends were chatting with her. This was me "Uhh huh, si, no, si, queso si.  Por favor. Aye, que cosas. "Anyways the food was great.  I had the enchiladas and we got Margaritas, I think.  

In my opinopn, this is way better than the Glen Park location, which is always crammed and stuffy and there's never anywhere to sit.  I usually get the spicy chicken burrito or cheese enchiladas.  Always good.  Oh yeah, the young ladies working behind the counter, though shy and soft spoken, throw it all together very nicely...the dude is always nice too.

I haven't been back since.  I thought I'd try and diversify my menu drawer portfolio, but I'd go back just to chop it up with the "lady with the blond hair". (please forgive me for forgetting her name and my lack of a better description)  There's something to be said when you leave a restaurant not only content that you've filled up with delicious food, but reassured that there are nice, down to earth people out there who go out of their way to make you feel special in their establishment.  Thank you!
author: Perry D.

description: Yes this place is amazingly good, the portions are large and the prices are fair. I never would've known to come in, but luckily I was with a local from that hood and he knew what was up. The only problem was that I should never order in Spanish, because I completely forgot what carne asada was and thought it was carnitas. Boo on that. My super yummy quesadilla was all beefy (which I don't eat) instead of porky which would of been awesome. My bad. But still it was loaded with everything delicious and huge. It also came w/ a little side salad, which added a nice touch. Next time I'm just going to stick with chicken! My friend ordered their beef w/ prawn combo meal and it was super good....the prawns were sauteed w/ onions and mushrooms and came with beans and rice and tortillas. I need to order that (besides the beef) next time I get a chance to go there!
author: Sonya D.

description:
Late Night on Mission for grub, this is the place to be! All walks of SF life wait in line for their fourth meal. The quesadilla came highly recommended Carne Asada Sousa with avocado, meat and cheese (no sour cream for me) and it was tasty. Folded in a nontraditional way and super huge...enough to share. 
My personal favorite was the El Pastor taco...meaty, fresh. The have a salsa bar but everything is really spicy (I think). 
-Reasonable scrumptious mexican food open late, plus beer if you really want...what's not to love?
author: Ashley B.

description:
This place just ousted Taqueria el Buen Sabor as my favorite burrito! 

I got a carnitas burrito that was huge. It had way more flavor than any of the other Mission burritos I've had. The salsa verde was awesome, as was their hot salsa. 

They have a decent selection of beer and plenty of seating. The employees were very friendly and efficient. I will be going back frequently.
author: Beth D.

description:
I need to stop forgetting to take water to the gym.  After working out at Mission Cliffs, we came here because the mango agua fresca was supposed to be really good.  It was but because I was very thirsty, I almost finished a large in one big slurp.  Then I got a strawberry one and it tasted like syrup.  Pass.

I also had a regular baby fish burrito which was pretty big.  It had salmon, rice, beans and salsa so it was very filling.  I didn't find it to be a wet burrito like I have read in other reviews.  

The place is huge, clean and open fairly late.
author: Seong P.

description:
I come to La Corneta for one thing and one thing only.  

The Salmon burrito!!

It's amazing!
author: Lauren C.

description:
I've had more than one person tell me that La Corneta was their favorite taqueria in SF so I had to give it a try. Also, it's less than a block from El Farolito so it has to be pretty decent to stay in business. I thought the food was pretty good just really bland. Honestly, it's like they sucked out all of the flavor and mailed it to El Farolito down the street. 

I tried in vein to find some spicy salsa or some bottled hot sauce but there was none to be found. If you like spiciness, or even just flavor in your food, you probably won't like La Corneta.
author: Aaron V.

description:
I'm normally an Al Pastor kinda gal, but they ran out so I subbed with some carnitas and 1 carne asada taco. Wasn't too thrilled about the carne asada, but I think I'm just over beef. But, the carnitas? Aye aye aye, BEST taco ever..like you will not find anything better, trust me on this people.
However, I must admit I was totally confused when she asked me what type of beans I wanted. So, I reiterated that I wanted tacos, not a burrito and she asked me again "what kind bean?". Good thing my pal is Puerto Rican and piped in with some Espanol to probably talk shit about me and say "sorry my friend is an idiot and she doesn't get that you put beans in your tacos, let me handle her"
Once she translated that they add beans to the tacos, I was still confused but she insisted I'd love em and would be fine.

It was a bonus that they served booze too so my friend and I had a drink with our food and talked of the financial Armageddon facing our country.
Kinda killed my buzz a little, but it was 'smart talk' and sometimes I need to hear about world issues through my friends since I only pick up newspaper to wrap knick knacks in when I move.

If you're in "the Mish" (apparently, that's what the hipsters call it), I insist you try this place over El Farolito because their chips are better, the seating is better and the people that work here aren't creepy pervs.
author: T C.

description:
It still amazes me how poor Taquerias are in SF and how easy it is to make this California version of Mexican food. Where to start?  The wait, horrific on most days and only because they have NO idea how to run a restaurant, they need to go to the Google and search  "Henry Ford". No he is not a burrito expert but he did pioneer the assembly line, something these folks must not know exists. Imagine if you went to a  restaurant and the waiter took your order, bussed your table and went back and cooked your it in addition to serving you, well that is how it is done here. I have been here when they have 10 employees behind the counter and can't serve 3 people in 10 minutes. If they did a traditional (logical and efficient) service they could serve a min of 5X the people in the same time conservatively. You regulars know what I mean, it's almost entertaining to watch them run around bumping into each other, at least if you have time to kill. To give you an idea of how bad it can be, I have called in an order when in line and then waled to pick up and got my food faster. Little tip there. 

Now the food. Like most profit-based cookie cutter Taquerias there is plenty of cost filler like rice and lettuce. A proper carne asada burrito does not have beans, rice and a bunch of greasy low grade chopped steak. At least La Taqueria in the Mission gets this and tries to do it right.   Nothing like pound of watery salsa to make the thing fall apart in your hands so you have a pile mush to eat with a fork. 

Let's move to tacos. Piles of beans inside, really? Why not add rice to be consistent and then you have an open faced SF burrito with a corn tortilla.  But wait! You can ask for no beans in your fish taco right!! Of course you can but be ready because that fish taco comes with Salmon not white fish. What a nice surprise as I really miss all those salmon fish tacos I have never had in Mexico. Was there a sale at Costco on Salmon. Where do you get a Salmon fish taco in Mexico?  Clearly a lazy cost cutting technique. 

The worst part is how many people wait in line for absurd amounts of time for what they believe is decent Mexican. This is not even a good representation of California Mexican. Even sadder is that the owners (I believe)  are Mexican which is rare here as the Mission is mostly Hondurans, Salvadorans, etc and a reason we have this poor Mexican food. 

Oh- The green "SF standard" salsa is pretty good though.
author: Mark D.

description: Quaint little place, plain decor, but TASTY food!  Get the horchata, it's delicious!  This was a perfect stop for a long road trip.
author: Jenny H.

description: Accidentally ended up here looking for another taqueria. It was clean, tasty, and fast mexican food. What more could you ask for when roaming around the Mission. I had the enchiladas, very tasty.
author: Chirag V.

description:
Stepping into the restaurant ..is like day and night. The streets of Mission are quite disgusting and unfortunately, I decided to make my first visit to the Mission street La Cornet and unforgettable experience. lol. Yet, once I was inside, I was pleasantly surprised by the bright atmosphere and the Mexican music. This place is much bigger and much prettier than the Glen Park location. The service was quick and efficient. I would love to come by and visit here again with a whole group of people. The only downside is that the sidewalks are really unsanitary...especially since I was wear sandals - silly me lol. All of their burritos are delicious and I love their vegetarian options too! The only reason I docked one star is because the other location will actually offer me salsa on the side with my chips...so now I've got lots of chips and no salsa ... uhoh, what will I do? hehe. Well, lucky me because I still have some trader joe's guac left over - Yay. ;)

So is it worth it to tread the unsanitary streets of Mission to get a meal at La Corneta? Yes, it is! Forget Taco Bell - Te Quiero La Corneta! 

PS
I think it's a cash only place...and yes, it's a bit pricey too - so just make sure you've got at least 10-20 bucks on you
author: Rachel A.

description: A burrito as big as my head and a tasty agua fresca fir under ten dollars?  Delish AND economical. Minus one star for inconsistent distribuition of cheese on my burrito.  Bonuses:  free chips and salsa and the bathroom does not look like a science fair project.
author: Sean H.

description:
This is one of my favorite mexican places in the mission.  It's clean, the burritos are huge, the carne asada is well-seasoned and slightly crispy the way it should be, and they give you squeeze bottles of salsa verde and salsa roja that go good with anything you order there.  Any restaurant that has squeeze bottles of good sauces on their tables for me to try gets an extra star in my book.  i guess that's why i like pho so much.  

Grace got the super nachos there and they were insane. So big.
author: William S.

description: Had my 33rd birthday burrito bash there last night.  I had met with the manager Miguel the week before and asked him if I could order some appetizers from him and bring in a cake.  He said, no problem.  I had 35 of my closest friends arrive at 7pm and he had tables set up, chips and salsa on the table and within minutes chicken flautas with guacamole served.  It was awesome.  Everyone ordered their own burritos and the consensus was that the food was excellent.  I was to busy mingling to eat my own burrito but it seems as if everyone was satisfied with their meals.  A few of my friends were delighted when they rolled in three sheets to the wind, that they could order 32 ounces of Corona.  They loved that!  Especially since they were celebrating 40 FRIDAY.  The customer service was excellent, and I will definitely have a burrito bash there again.
author: Mar M.

description:
Taqueria's come a-plenty in the mission and it may be hard to choose but if you're looking to grub on good fish tacos you should go to la corneta. If you order a super, you get a huge piece of salmon, generous portions of frijoles, guacamole, rice and salsa. Their salmon was yummy, not greasy either! Always a plus at a taqueria. Although the guacamole totally negates the health factor! Chips were a little greasy too. But I'll live :)

I was in great spirits while I ate there with friends. So many different elements set the mood! There was a live musician playing guitar and singing for the patrons. I think he plays on Saturdays. The decor is also super cute. They make the inside of their restaurant look similar to the outside of spanish styled casas in Mexico. I felt really festive and like I was dining at a lively joint south of the border. The manager came around, noticed that I had a hearty appetite and recommended that I try the posole the next time around. She was a sweetie! And you know what, I just might.

I hope the same musician is there the next time I come!
author: Geralyn Y.

description:
Sexually harassed by the drunk owner. 

nuff said.
author: Marcia O.

description:
We came here on a whim. Personally, I've never been here before, and it was one of the only Taqueria's open at the time, so we took a shot and came here. I ordered the Enchilada plate, while my bf got a Super Quesidilla. All in all, the orders came to $17. 

They brought the food to our table, and it looked REALLY good before we touched it, but once I started eating, I noticed how plain the food tasted. So I added some of their hot sauce/salsa but it's REALLY watered down, and not the least bit spicy. I ate about a quarter of it and called it quits! I took the food home, only to not waste it. But it wasn't as great as I thought it would be. 

The location is in a sketched part of SF, also. I don't think I will come back, unless I'm desperately starving at 9:30PM.
author: Denise D.

description:
After my near-mind-blowing visit to the La Corneta in Glen Park (http://www.yelp.com/user_details_review_search?userid=e331pQV1I-SSnWw_w0PfMA&q=corneta)   I had to check out their Mission location when I was in a hood a few weeks ago.

Unfortunately, I am sad to report that it wasn't as good, as I was able to pay full attention to what my brother was saying....

He was talking about......wait, crap, I forgot.

Ok, so maybe the Steak and Prawn Quesadilla wasn't so bad. But definitely not as tasty as Glen Park. Still points for having SPQ but it didn't pack enough heat, and their horchata was too watery.

Points for have a huge seating area.
author: Faffy L.

description:
So a bunch of us were going to go to el farolito that is a couple doors down from la corneta. 

Then some of us were not really feeling so safe here, little bit of a sketchy crowd, and from a friend's past experience I'm told that it wouldn't be a good thing if we got stuck near a bar fight since el farolio was connected to the bar next door. Some of us don't really like being in the mission. Ok, Fair enough.

Walked down the block to la corneta, the digs didn't seem as hole in the wall, down home, authentic, dirty tacos, but it'll have to do. Actually it was freaking well lit as heck and way cleaner (and gringo-ed out) than el farolito since it's a chain type restaurant, but yelp tells me this place got at least 4 stars, so we weren't in for an experience, but we wouldn't be eating crappy burritos and tacos. 

This place is pretty much the same to me as poncho villa. Its good, but you kind of expect a place like this to at least be this good, so there was nothing that floored me, but at least it's safer, cleaner, and has TONS of seating. Since the venue was nicer, you could safely assume that you would be paying like a dollar more for a burrito here than el farolito down the block.

I would like to eventually make my way over for a quick bite at el farolito tho. It did have a good sized line building around 8pm on a Sunday night. Where as there was pretty much no wait at la corneta. If you like to live semi-dangerously, please try el farolito out and tell me how good it is :)


FOOD:
Bottled water is $0.92, you know what, it's such a simple pleasure, but you RARELY see bottled water for under a dollar at restaurants and convenience stores. 

I had the super taco. Comes with two soft corn tortillas, and literally a pile of food on top. I had the carne asada (grilled beef), so it came will a generous portion of meat, sour cream, avocado, lettuce, shredded cheese, salsa, pico de gallo (chopped up tomatoes and cilantro and lime ish salsa), beans, rice, slice of tomato and a wedge of a lime. It was pretty super to me. All this for $4.50! I was pretty filled up.

Got a large churro (filled with creme or something), it wasn't warm, so I was disappointed, but I would not hesitate to try one again if it was fresh out of the deep fryer. The texture of the dough of the churro is WAY different from churros you get at Costco (best value churro in the entire bay area that I know of... although I do see those dudes carrying a cart of home made churros that they sell on the streets). The ridges on this churro kind of crumble? I don't know if I'm using the right word to describe it, but its def different when you bite into it. 

They give you a generous basket of huge chips and lots of pico de gallo salsa. I had no complaints. If you want more salsa, just ask for it, they don't gripe. 

Would I come back? Maybe, only to try a warm fresh churro, only because there are so many other 'yelp 4 star' taquieras in the misson that I still need to try.
author: Irene C.

description:
BABY BURRITO?!?!?!?!

Yes, please!!  

It is not much smaller than the regular burrito, I will admit, but the fact that it is supposed to be makes me feel better about eating it in all its deliciousness.

Good guacamole, steamed tortillas, crazy clean, friendly service.
author: Megan D.

description:
You steam a tortilla, you only get three stars. That's the rule.

Before I got tired of the yummy greasy affair that is the Can Cun "vegetarian" burrito I never ate here because I couldn't see the point in ordering a steamed tortilla with cold cheese and lettuce on top of  otherwise decent ingredients, but having discovered the fish burrito, which begins with a fresh filet of salmon, I have to say that there is one thing I will overlook a steamed tortilla for: a fresh filet of salmon--with spanish rice, black beans, and salsa. That's all. Simple as can be, less than $8 (salmon prices what they are that ain't bad),  and absolutely delicious. Your cats will pester you if you get one to go, but throw them a little piece of fish and you'll be fine. There's plenty to go around if you get the big boy size.
author: Erik S.

description:
FREE BEER IS NOT a good influence for an objective review but heck, Bakesale Betty gives out free cookies at the least provocation ("oh you have a boo-boo? here's a cookie" THOUGH I NEVER GOT ONE) and people give it good ratings (only explanation I see cause the sandwich is a soggy mess) so here I go with La Corneta, where I arrived on an empty stomach cause I went to Day of the Dead which perhaps due to the nazoid suppression of Halloween in SF has turned into an ersatz mexi-goth fest (ok, mostly goths) playing batucada and kecak music (hello, Mexico, not Brazil/Bali) and the lines for tacos where hugely long and so I didn't eat till 10:45 pm when I arrived at La Corneta.

And the boss or something gave us a free beer (Negra Modelo, !que buen gusto!) because the line was going very sloooowly and I was thirsty so I guzzled the beer and was ripped by the time I got to the cash register because I'm a lightweight but not before I ordered my Holy Trinity of tacos (carnitas/pastor/asada), well actually, scratch the asada because I wasn't that hungry and these tacos were $2.25 a piece AND had beans so I guessed they might be a little bigger.

So I got them and a plastic basket of chips and DAMN these were some big tacos.  A lot of meat, plus refried beans on the bottom (really wanted black but whatever) oh and did I mention I had to eat them in 30 minutes because I needed to catch BART?  So I ate them like David Hasselhoff, big greasy hands mess, but damn:

THESE CARNITAS ARE PRETTY GOOD

I mean moist and smoky and a little roasted too and I ate them with my tortillas but there was so much meat it spilled out so I scooped it up with the chips too.  And the salsa from the one of the squeeze bottles was fiery. Hooray!

Now the Pastor was just OK -- I should just give up on ever getting a Pastor taco even half as good as what you can get at any taqueria in Mexico but it was also plentiful, and I couldn't even finish the tacos.  I kept drinking my beer.  I once went to get water too and realized I couldn't find my own table... oh there it is... and I was distrac-- did you see that girl over there in the sweater?  What do they feed them? Whoa... 

Got em mostly down (leaving the second tortilla, which I never do but I was stuffed) and bolted out to BART where I made the train on time.  The buzz lasted til home where I wrote this and I say that even you don't get a free beer FOUR STARS FOR LA CORNETA!!!!!!!!!!!

Looking for more Mexican?  See my Mexican food list here:
http://www.yelp.com/list_details?list_id=7moDaSk5jQWRZ76X3AbyFA
author: Daniel S.

description: IMO, way better than most of the highly rated burrito/taco spots on Yelp. Simple fast food, no frills. Quality food and reasonable prices. Great flavors, great chips & salsa for free. Don't miss the agua de orchata; it's a winner. Warning: Tacos are huge ... if you're a light eater start with one and take it from there.
author: Graeson N.

description:
Everyone has his/her favorite taqueria in San Francisco, and this one is mine. Their food is consistently excellent, and the place is absolutely spotless. (I'm not the kind of person who can turn a blind eye toward filth in a restaurant, no matter how good the food is. There are several taquerias in SF I can't stomach.)

If there is a heaven, they'll be serving La Corneta super steak and prawn quesadillas when I stroll through the pearly gates. Yum.
author: The Other Jeff A.

description:
For so long I passed over La Corneta because it looked nice from the outside- I assumed it was for gringos who didn't know better. I don't know why I thought this- as this is at the 24th street end of the Mission and Pancho Villa/ 16th street is where more Gringos and Hipsters hang out, but I did. So, when the girls from my afterschool program at Horace Mann Middle School, located in the heart of the mission at 23rd and bartlett, only 1/2 block away from the Bart Station, had a heated debate over the superiority of La Corneta vs El Farolito, I took notice of this place. 12 year old girls definitely know whats up-- if legit mission residents were into it, I had to give it a try.

Four months later I am totally converted from El Farolito.

The truth is, you don't have to wait in dirty booths at Can-Cun or El Farolito for good Mexican food in the Mission (at least until 11pm when then this place closes). There is something appealing about being able to enjoy your meal at a clean table with your friends!

They have a variety of meats (al pastor, chile verde) and seafood (camarones diablo!!) for tacos, quesadilllas, and burritos of varied sizes (from super to baby- which you can finish without feeling totally nauseous). Their nachos are totally enormous and yummy. I like their baby burrito- a great value and totally filling. Some people seem to have a beef with this place, but I think the food is good enough for take out too- not just for its superiority for ambiance dining in.
author: Lizzie C.

description:
No longer in SF, I dream of La Corneta super baby chicken burritos on a regular basis.  I know everyone has their favorite taqueria, but La Corneta is mine.  It's sooooooooooooooooooo good!!!!  And the baby burrito is the perfect size when you want to eat a whole burrito without a) feeling guilty or b) lapsing into a coma.  *drool*

Why can't anyone in DC make a proper burrito?
author: sarah K.

description:
I just remembered how often I would go to La Corneta when I lived at 22nd and Valencia and my ex would go out to do stenciling and I would be the lookout. I miss those days. 

Anyway, La Corneta is really good. It's very easy to overlook it in favor of the more bad ass El Farolito and overrated Papalote, but actual Mexican people come here and they have lots of options. I loved grilled mushroom and steak baby burrito with a Tecate or their enchiladas or chips & guacamole. My old office would get catering from them occasionally and it was always such a great day to be able to eat La Corneta for free. I miss this place.
author: Maria D.

description:
The staff is efficient and fast, and I love the whole Mexican-Indoor Plaza motiffe of the building.  The line moves swiftly, and the food rocks.  There's a cold beer in the cooler at the end, and along with a salmon super taco (which is a lot of food, by the way), dinner has been accomplished for around nine dollars altogether---which includes the tip and the beer.

TIP: Ask for the tortillas on the side.  The super taco includes a lot of food, and if the tortillas are buried underneath that mountain of food, well, you just can't lift it up.  I separate the tortillas and get a couple of tacos out of it.  Also, las muchachas tend to be more generous with the portions when they don't have to put it all on top of a tortilla.

Luis y yo vamos a veces a la Taqueria Corneta para un super taco de salmon despues de un larga dia de trabajo.  Suena como no se incluya mucho, un oredenito de un super taco de salmon, pero si le pides con las tortillas (porque siempre te dan dos) aparte, te dan un plato que se incluya frijoles (a mi me gustan los negros), un pedaso de salmon, bien fresco y asado en el momento, tirado ensima de una cama de lechuga, crema, aguacate, y quezo; y hay que probechar sus salsas incredibles tambien.  Pide limon, chips, y una cervecita, y despues de pagar la propina, haz pagado como nueve dolares y...!!Rrrrrrrrrriquisima!!
author: Randy F.

description:
I had a hankering for some street tacos, but my health conscious friend took me here.  Fine.  I had a feeling flavor was going to be compromised, somehow.

When I saw the tray of churros, some that were cream-filled.. .I got ekchited.

I tasted their al pastor, which was alright.  I opted to get the carne asada taco with black beans (already a healthy option).  

The taco was okay.  It did taste "healthy", which means I wasn't satisfied after the meal.  The cream-filled churro wasn't fresh nor flavorful.  My diet coke was cool, not ice cold.

I guess I'll just stick to the rivers and the lakes that I'm used to, and go straight to the taco trucks.

(  |  )
author: Grace M.

description: this place has the best carne asada  plate in mission area
author: Juan M.

description:
I Actually despise eating here when Farolitos is so freaking close so let's keep this sweet.

Good Tacos - 1 Star
OK fine, REALLY good tacos - 1 Star
Credit Card Acceptance - 3 Stars
Proximity to Farolito's - negative 1 star
Lack of True Carnitas Burrito Solution - negative 1 star

Update: Beer and being "sunny" - 1 star
author: Tyler W.

description:
This is by far the most upscale taqueria I've visited in the Mission. Glass entry doors, a juice bar, bright lighting, and live music in the atrium. Need more proof? They have a location on Burlingame Avenue.

I was back in the Bay Area for a very short week, and as I tried to eat as much Mexican food as possible, I really REALLY wanted to like this place. I'd already had my fix of burritos, tacos and quesadillas, so when I saw tamales on the menu, I got excited. 

Only to be disappointed. The chicken inside was all dark meat, and the texture of the tamal was rubbery. They melted cheese on top, which was new to me. I normally like to take my tamales out from the corn husks. It's part of the fun. Redeeming qualities: warm chips and delicious salsas in those squeezy bottles.
author: Dave K.

description:
As a long-time Pancho Villa [what the hell happened to the free salsa?] burritonista, I can now say without a shadow of a doubt, La Corneta kicks carne asada!
For such a busy establishment, the place is both efficient and neat as a pin. While chips are not the reason to partake of LCT's vittles mexicana, they were crispy, light and still warm. I had the Shrimp Quesadilla. It was stuffed to the gills with tasty shrimp, and all the requisite fix'ns. A live band was singing Guantanamara, while the brood feasted on chicken tacos, and quesadillas. All ingredients were very fresh. 
I'd say, La Corneta rocks!
author: Mr. S.

description:
When im craving for  a Carna Asada and Prawns plate. I go here..why you ask????

1)the price 9.95 
2)its huge
3)its taste good
author: Eko A.

description: Meh, not the worst but really not that great. Not fresh-mex but not authentic. Got the super burrito so other items might be better. Will not be coming back.
author: Melanie W.

description: We come here at least twice a month.  My favorite is the shrimp baby burrito or splitting a platter of the carne asada and shrimp, which comes with rice, beans, and tortillas. Top it off with a fresa or melon agua fresa, and you're set. Very clean, and very delicious.
author: Vanessa H.

description:
Fairly clean and spacious restaurant where the majority of patrons are mexican and suggested by our friend of the same team.
Very inexpensive compared to other restaurants.
Good for post drunken dolores park beach blanket assaults.
author: G K.

description:
Has La Corneta been farting up dust or what lately?

Anyone been eating here since it opened? I really think the quality has gone conspicuously downhill. Granted, I may reasonably have eaten, say, 433 burritos here, so the wheels were bound to fall off sometime.

I've just noted a blandness to all the flavors here recently, a coldness to the end product. Granted, this is still one of the SF taquerias where I think you're least likely to get a wallop of food poisoning, so you've got that going for you...
author: Jeremy W.

description:
Once upon a time I actually really enjoyed this Taqueria. That was before I started out hanging out with this mexican girl who later became my bff. She introduced me to real flavor and seasoning. Now I know that La Corneta is dull and flavorless. :-/

I must say though that the staff is always friendly and accomodating and the restaurant is clean.
author: Risa R.

description:
This is another fabulous Mission taqueria.  Ah, but Todd, there are dozens to choose from, why should I go further?  

What separates La Corneta rom the pack are the wonderful seafood options.  The fish taco has a fat sliver of crispy grilled salmon filet, the prawns are butterflied, deveined, juicy and perfectly grilled.  Trust me, anything seafood at this place is top drawer.  The other items are rather pedestrian, but get a fish taco, or prawn burrito, and you'll be blown away.

Another thing I have noticed about this place is it's immaculate dining area.  At first, I was suspicious, I usually feel more at home with the holes in the wall.  But after several trips here, I realized hey, it's clean!  It's not because it's new, or not busy, they just keep the place squeaky clean.  If your family comes to town and you don't want to squeeze them into El Farolito, take them here.
author: Todd E.

description:
This is probably the "cleanest" Taqueria on Mission and also the one with the healthiest toppings, almost like a salad with all the colors. 
Their super nachos are full of fresh avocado, lots of fresh tomato, lettuce, delicious beans  and sour cream. When I buy their nachos it feels healthier because of all the fresh vegetables and colors, compared to for example 

I recently tried " El Metate"  (daytime) and this reminds me how much I enjoy a clean place!... yes, El Metate is pretty and happy (very Mexican) but not clean... La Corneta is just as happy and colorful and SUPER clean..!.. I really dislike going to Taquerias and feeling rushed because they are just not a place to "sit and hang out with a cup of coffee (they do sell coffee too!) .. except here. 

Their Flan with Chocolate is also delicious.
author: Geena T.

description:
Our group of 5 friends stumbled into this place Saturday 1/22/11 for lunch because a lot of the other restaurants around the Mission area did not have enough seating (we originally wanted to eat at Mr Pollo, but that place was TINY and no outdoor seating available). Its a beautiful restaurant, very clean (including the restrooms), ample seating, and nice music from a live band. 
The food itself was OK...my carnitas tacos were bland, despite the big portions. My friends enjoyed their burritos and plates. But the HORRIBLE thing about this place is that (1) They don't post their prices on their menu board, which (2) led us to be overcharged. I paid almost $28 for 3 carnitas tacos, a veggie burrito, a mexican coke and arizona ice tea. How was it this much, you might wonder??
The tacos were $3.00 each so a total of $9.00. Veggie burrito was $3.45. Drinks were $1.50 and $1.05, fine there. But the guy at the cash register charged me for an extra THREE carnitas tacos!  So I paid an extra $9.00 for ghost tacos. I didn't question it at the time because again, no prices posted on the menu board. If there are prices on the board, you cannot see them with the naked eye. That and you'd have to be behind the counter to see it. But I really don't remember seeing the prices. My girl friend paid $30 for a burrito and a combo plate and two drinks. She thought it was ridiculously high too, but we figured it was due to the fact that the place was big (this is SF, rent must be expensive) and live entertainment. I didnt' realize till later that evening that we got ripped off. And this happened to my sister's boyfriend, in another instance. He said he got charged for two burritos when he only got one. He got the run around at the restaurant when he brought the error up ("My supervisor isn't available, you will have to wait for him" and he did wait), but eventually got his money back. I would've gone back but I live in Sacramento, and didn't want to pay the $5 bay bridge toll + gas to drive out there again to make a point there. So this is why I'm posting it on Yelp. If you go to La Corneta Taqueria, make sure you pay attention to what they are charging you, and if it seems abnormally high, question them on what each item costs. I think its EXTREMELY shady to have a menu board that does not post their prices. All the more room for them to overcharge you. Not going there again.
author: Jasmine M.

description:
This is a clean, well lighted place for burritos. They do a good al pastor, not greasy, flavorful, nice. Sometimes I want the grease though, in which case I head to El Farolito on 24th.

The carnitas was not good this last time. I don't know if it was just a bad day, or it's always like that ... I could taste the oil in the carnitas, kinda rancid. I couldn't finish my burrito. :(

Nevertheless, I've had positive experiences here any other time.
author: Taj M.

description:
"Super-size it!" I can holler into a McD's drive-thru, and not fear a thing (not that I normally do, but I can without a second thought).  
Girl can eat.  And girl can drink, too.  :-)

But at this place, think once, twice, thrice before you utter anything "super ______".  They don't kid around with super.

Now, I remind you again, lest you forget, I can eat. 
But the "Super Steak/Prawn Quesadilla" that was ordered for me at La Corneta was enormous.  At first, I'm thinking, "Hmm... will I be full on just one quesadilla, super or not?" and then when it came flying in looking like half a XL pizza (ok maybe a slight exaggeration but the thing was barely closing on itself because it was so full of "stuff")..... I was officially worried.
That ain't no Taco Bell Quesadilla, friends.  Welcome to the world of giants.

I finished half with some work, and even then, I was full for the remainder of the day.  The only reason I could finish half was because of the perfectly toasted flour tortilla, and the fresh, juicy fillings, with lots of fresh guacamole, sour cream, lettuce, etc. that was too good to pass up....  I suspect most girls will finish about 1/4 of  this quesadilla, so dining "family-style" might be wise....

The establishment is bright and pleasant, and they have some nice seating in one section of the restaurant for a near "patio-dining" effect.  During lunch, it was pretty crowded, and I suspect the same will hold true for dinner.  Location was a bit fishy, but I didn't feel my life was in danger at any point.  Staff was so-so, but nothing to complain about.

Oh, and they have two kinds of salsa, one is mild and the other is hot, with fresh bits of jalapeno.  Now, for me, this was no challenge, but if you can't handle spicy - - go for the first, or pick out the jalapeno bits.  I didn't try the mild version but I could just eat up spoonfuls of the second one all day long and be happy.  Combined bite by bite with my quesadilla, it was perfect.

I glanced around and noticed almost everything is big here.  It's not "fast food cheap" either, as lunch for two with two super quesadillas and two drinks was *almost* $20 if I recall correctly.  But service is fast, and the food is tasty and fresh.  Speaking of drinks - we tried the "horchata", I think it was called, and it was quite complementary to our food.  It's like sugar water with a good dose of cinnamon, what I imagine a churro to taste like if blended with water?  Doesn't sound appetizing but it was actually quite good.

A strong 3-stars for the food, and an additional 1 star simply for being almost OVERLY generous with sizing.  While this meant i could not finish my meal, it does mean a big guy with a hearty apetite would walk out of here very, very, very happy.  :-)

FYI - according to their menu, there are four locations, 2 in SF, one in Burlingame, and one in Redwood City.  They do take-out, phone orders, and have gift certificates.  Also, if planning a group event or big party -  they will also cater for you.  Not shabby at all!
author: Grace K.

description: Oh man, you need to take this one off your list. There are SO many better taquerias in the Mission: Vallarta, San Francisco, El Matate, Paplote, La Palma, La Espiga De Oro, the list goes on!!
author: john v.

description:
I don't care what people think about this place, from 4 stars and under. This place has some great food. Everyone says this place is clean which is a must and they are VERY clean. My gf and I have been comming here for almost a year now and almost 2 times a week. yea, I use my whole paycheck for this place. ( My suga mama pays 90% of the time, thanks sucka) I just can't get enough of the super taco. Eveyrthing is fresh, especially the salsa and food. Nice selection of beer/ drinks. No fountain soda though.

If you are reading this, trust me and go try this place out. Of all places on Mission, try this one first. You don't have to listen to me, but if you are reading my review all the way to the second paragraph, your mouth is already salivating and you are map-questing this restaurant already.

Enjoy because I want to go again soon.
author: David L.

description:
One of my favorite taqueria's in the Mission.  I love their baby burritos and they are so cheap too.  How can you go wrong with only $3.50?  It's the perfect size to munch on and leaves you full for the rest of the day.

Bonus:  Large dining room and very clean.
author: Cynthia C.

description: This place is great! It was a bit crowded but its understandable,,,,the food is so good. Authentic Mexican Food. I am really picky with mexican food because I have been spoiled with grandmas cooking. I hate when I go to  a "mexican" restaurant and the food is generic. Not this place, I took my grandmother here and she approved! The Horchata is so good, almost as good as my grandmas ...pretty close. They have live music on the weekends which gives the dining experience an extra ""UMMFF""  lol I highly recommend this Place. I had a chicken burrito with a side of beans and rice. So good. Its pretty big but it will be hard to find parking as its on Mission st. A very busy St.
author: karen g.

description:
Ok this place, is a good place. It is a clean and bright and wide and open. Light descends from above in main room. Nice people. La comida es excelente. I done order a salmon burrito and a fresh squeezed OJ and, well, it was all hella good 'n shit, aight but then I realized that I left my assfuck debitorcredit card in the mothercock ATM at the plasticdouche Safeway which means I gotta get it to go AIGHT? Well the ATM ate my bitchass card and I ate the burrito at home black beans whole wheat tortilla salmonguac good. The OJ is for manana where is the tilda in plaintext.

I will return to this place. I believe in this place. It is a good place. Kinda like a church, but rather than Maria and JC, food and light are god.

Natural Light: Excellent/Outstanding
author: Mark G.

description: My boyfriend and i have been to this spot 3 times our first time there was very nice the food was fresh and tasty and we even had a lady come over to our table and sing a couple songs. the 2nd time there was ok my chicken was a little under cooked but i didn't have a complaint about anything else. My boyfriends brother on the other hand found a hair in his nachos and was discusted. Now my 3rd time there was yesterday we all went in around lunch time and ordered there Cesar salad that's topped with yummy grilled chicken. well apparently they do not wash the lettuce they buy because we found a black beatle in my boyfriends mothers salad and it was still alive! uughh! we had all ordered a salad so we told the waiter that we did not want anything anymore. This place is nice and the chicken is good but if they do not wash there lettuce it makes me question just how careful they are about handling the rest of the food. i give them 1 star for having good grilled chicken and for there DELICIOUS SANGRIA but that is all.
author: Claudia R.

description:
I used to eat at Corneta A LOT. Way back in 2001 I worked on 21st and Mission and frequently went there for lunch. I made friends with the manager, who told me he was the owner's son. I can't remember his name but he was always super nice  to me and whoever I brought in there with me. Sometimes he would be flirty, but nothing too weird. I did get a sense he was a pervert on the DL, but it didn't bother me.

One night  I went in there and he chatted me up for a really long time and then he walked me 24th street. I thought it was funny, but I was like, oh he's just being friendly. So we get to the bart station and I say "okay well, good night" and he lunges at me and attempts to stick his tongue down my throat! I don't really remember what I said but I know I booked it down those stairs and ran to hop on a train as fast as I could.

The next few weeks I fretted about it, cuz while I wasn't really mad at him, I felt like I couldn't go in there to get food. And that made me sad. Eventually I returned to Corneta and the guy was just nice as usual, maybe a bit quiet, maybe a bit embarrassed. I never brought it up. That was so long ago, and the last few times I went there more recently he wasn't there. I have been informed that he was fired, and also that he was NOT the owner's son! 

So all that being said, Corneta's food isn't exactly spectacular(especially with the other neighborhood options). But I do really like that it's clean and fresh and the fish items are typically good.  But my favorite item on the menu is the super tostada. They make the shells there, and even without any meat, it is an explosion of flavor. Just make sure you get a couple lime wedges to squeeze over it. Delicious.

Oh also, for whatever reason, they have the best refried beans. I believe they're vegetarian, but I could be wrong. They are scrumptious, and whenever I order I always get a side to go.
author: Andi R.

description: I LOVE comming here, one of my favorite places, I always get there grilled chicken supper burrito, with spinach tortilla, really good.. I'm not sure about there drink menu, but where they have there sodas and other drinks, they have few options for beers, there Sangria is good. I'm not too sure if they have more drink options.. anyway, there prices are really good, and give you lots of food.. a supper baby burrito would be probably around $6.75 or so, a regular around $7 maybe 8.. they do have a band that plays there almost every few days, or every other day.. they have there own desserts, lots of food choices, different meats, there veggiterian burrito is also VERY good.. they know how to stuff a burrito, lol.. this would be one of my main places to come to if I want Mexican food...
author: Mariana O.

description:
So La Corneta has been my post-bassooning taco place for the past year or so.  I take an evening chamber music class at the nearby Community Music Center and am always hungry for tacos after.  (Pavlovian?  Maybe.)
Anyways, I've tried a number of the taquerias around the 22nd/Mission area, and while, La Corneta isn't the best, it's clean, reasonably good, has chille rellenos, takes plastic and is a non-threatening option for a short girl dining alone with a bassoon.  I hear they operate a couple other eateries under the same name, so I suppose they have a standard and reputation to keep up. 
Overall: Not the best or cheapest, but reliable.
author: Kri B.

description: A bright, spacious, festive atmosphere with more or less the same quality food as other decent taquerias in the area. There's enough space for groups.
author: Inigo M.

description:
Yes, i still come here. i. can't. stop. but! things have gotten better. sort of? one of the ladies told my coworkers and i that the manager spoke with them all about our experience with the mean-makeup-red hat lady. EMBARRASSING! but, it had to be done. After this, if she approached us to take our order, we politely declined and waited for the next available worker. Now, she completely ignores us and goes to the people behind us. FINALLY- i dont have to interact with her!!! AND i get my burrito (ps- the nachos are also amazing)! 

one new thing: the younger guy with light eyes that usually is ringing up the orders has been hitting on me. would be ok if it was TASTEFUL.. and not borderline harassing and creepy! but if i politely decline his advances i'm worried i won't be able to get my burrito. YES, it's worth it.
author: p j.

description:
YUM! Ahhh...just remembering the days of living just a few blocks from this place ( a huge perk considering the lack of parking in the area!) 

Fast service, clean and yummy food...sounds like a winner to me!
author: Tiffany E.

description: I have been going to the La Corneta in Glen Park since it opened.  I was planning an event for an internal conference and we wanted to cater some delicious Mexican food.  La Corneta was super easy, brought us an entire delicious spread for a very reasonable price.  I would definitely use their catering for future events.
author: Gina I.

description:
Bland--that pretty much sums up everything at La Corneta.  I have a pretty shitty memory, so I end up eating here a fair amount, and I have eaten pretty much every meat on the menu.  I'm not sure how you can make al pastor or chile verde taste like flavorless paste, but La Corneta does it.  All three salsas (pico de gallo, rojo, verde) also taste like nothing.

I guess I'm always fooled by the daytime lines at this place.  I'm not sure why all these people are lined up for this non-tasty food, but sometimes I fall victim to groupthink and jump in line, only to bemoan my decision not to go to Farolito, La Taqueria, Taco Loco, San Jose, Altena, Guadalajara, or any of the other taquerias in a two block radius that are way better (and some of those listed aren't even that sweet).  That said, I'll probably be back eating here in two weeks, like an idiot.

Two stars for being a clean space and being in the same building as the mysterious "Jet Pack Living."  I would look you up on Google, but I prefer to let my imagination run wild.
author: David C.

description:
Delicious super baby burrito in clean, bright surroundings with lots of tables.  This is what El Toro used to be like back in the day...  except I could actually inhale a full size super burrito and the super baby option didn't exist.

Apart from the burritos and the environment, which are big pluses in my book, I have a lot of unfulfilled expectations.  Aguas frescas are too diluted with ice.  Chips need some salting.  No self-serve condiment bar.   I only get burritos 'to go' here.  They overwrap their burritos with foil (can mean unskilled composition and formation - loose burrito) and don't give you the plate and silverware necessary to really hunker down and do sloppy, carnivorous surgery and full-on salsa soaking.
author: Esther R.

description:
Diggin' it because they do *chico* burritos!  I would love to find more places that will actually make me a small size burrito.  Why do all SF taquerias insist on making HUGE burritos?  I don't get it.  

But...  they lose points for steaming their tortillas and putting lettuce in the burritos.  Lettuce?  No.  And tortillas should be grilled.  C'mon.  

Damn decent, tho.  The bean and cheese burrito is straight up.  :-)
author: J Liberty S.

description:
I know I shouldn't like this place. It's too clean. Too yellow. Too corporate. And if you put me on the spot, I will choose Papalote for the spectacular salsa and the juicy grilled chicken or El Farolito for the down-and-out factor. But there's something about La Corneta's baby burritos and quesadillas that makes me come back when I need to feel safe, unadventurous and cozy.

Maybe they put happy-pills in their salsa fresca. Cause I seem to be drawn to anything with their salsa fresca. Hmmmm. Happy-pill-salsa-fresca. I think I'm heading to the Mission.
author: Tatjana G.

description:
I have gone to my fair share of Mexican joints here in SF and I must say that this is definitely one of my favorites.
Forget the fact that the place has a chain-restaurant look to it.  Forget that their food is "just" a bit over-priced compared to competitors in the area.
The food is fantastic. The ingredients are fresh and the portions are massive.

I went today and got a "baby" burrito which was totally filling (a smaller version of their ginormous regular burrito...not a burrito made of babies)
I also have to give them props on their salmon burrito. Im usually a bit hesitant about getting fish at fairly fast food establishments, but the salmon was quite fresh and very delicious.

Highly recommended.
author: Fernando M.

description:
La Corneta is... the most beautiful taqueria I've ever been too. They ought to make the Mural in the center courtyard a part of a walking mural tour, it's that lovely. 

These folks are all about throughput - be quick on your feet and don't steer too far away from the extensive menu if you want to get what you expect -- i.e. don't be high maintenance.  I wouldn't recommend ordering takeout because I have never gotten exactly what i wanted - whether it's beef mixed into my chicken burrito (random, but has happened twice), or something trivial like the type of salsa.

Vegetarians, prepare to have random pieces of meat in your food once in a while. 

Fun spot overall - quick, cheap, tasty eats, nice venue, sometimes live music, and special desserts on special occasions in one of the most vibrant districts of San Francisco.
author: Maulie D.

description:
The last stop on our taco crawl.  This was the biggest, most "corporate" feeling taqueria of our day, but the menu was also the biggest, and the food was amazing.  I had a regular sized fish taco, (came with chips too) -- but this was no ordinary fish taco.  I'm used to southern cal style fish tacos, but this was more of a salmon tostada.  The salmon was *amazing*

Best of all, though, they had real glass-bottled coke, imported from mexico, with sugar instead of corn syrup.   So great.
author: DH H.

description: Favorite taqueria on Mission Street. Clean, nicely lit and everything I've tried has been amazing. Staff is super friendly. The ingredients are fresh and you can see your food being prepared right in front of you. Definitely try out one of their fruit juices, not something you can get everywhere.
author: Natalie D.

description:
I've been a fan of La Corneta for several years and am still gaga for it. What makes this place special is the freshness and quality of the ingredients. They don't use the industrial grade days old crap that lots of their competitors do. Everything is fresh and oh so tastey.

The menu is a little overwhelming the first time you go there. If you're accustomed to the standard Mission taqueria you don't expect to see more than about a dozen things on the menu. Here you have several dozens.

The fabulous fish burritos and tacos are made with salmon. As red meats go I love the carne asada (steak) and al pastor (pork). If you're really hankering for quadruple bypass surgery next week try the super nachos with carne asada. Truly amazing! Don't let the fact that this place is clean scare you away. An absence of roaches doesn't translate into an absence of authenticy or flavor.
author: Alan R.

description: I agree with Gwynnie P. on this one - I recently had a low paying gig a couple blocks away, and I took the opportunity to hit La Corneta again. The once famous San Francisco burrito has long devolved into a flour tortilla bulging with rice, so why wait in line for it? La Corneta has plenty of room, its cheery, the people who work there aren't suffering from caucasion exposure fatigue, and my burrito had peas in it. Plus they had a  tuneful band, a conga player and a guy on keyboards and vocals, that stepped everything up a notch.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I love this taqueria.
Great to take out a friend.
Great Burritos.
Great Horchata (sometimes it has it's days....but once in while!)
Great Food.
Love the live music.
I do think this location is better then the one on Diamond St. over on Glen Park. I think there is a difference in taste sometimes, and yes i order the same exact food.
Only thing is parking can sometimes get difficult when really hungry!
It gets really packed during lunch so if you come during lunch.
Be prepared to wait for a little while.
author: Nelson F.

description: One of my favorite Mexican food joints in the city. The salsa verde is crackin. Soooo good. Love the plates of food here. The enchiladas are awesome. Their refried beans are superb. The plates of food are totally gigantic, and great chips. Can't go wrong here. You will be stuffed if you get a plate, be prepared for a happy nap after. Yum.
author: Brooke A.

description: Decent place with VERY good burritos. I highly recommend the baby burritos. Its cheap and very good, like seriously the combination of the salsa, rice and beans is perfect i must say.
author: Cavin T.

description:
This was my first experience at La Corneta:

Ghetto patron w/ family & small children- "Can I have a cup for Corona to go?"

Cashier - "No." 

Ghetto patron - "WTF?!  I paid for my shit!  Give it to me!"

Cashier - "Sir you cannot take alcohol outside."

Ghetto patron - "I ain't takin' outside, I'm takin' it in my car!"


Oh yeah... this place rules.  Best taqueria in SF.
author: Larry A.

description:
La Corneta. Some here say "Mahhh. Not the greatest Burrito place."  I don't disagree, but I think that too much time is spent looking for "the greatest burrito place".  La Conrneta may not be the Platonic perfection of burrito places, but it makes a fine burrito, it's quick, not skimpy on the avocado/guacamole, provides tasty black beans, has some nice selections (tostadas and ceviche), and the food is fresh.

The prawns are especially excellent, but I approve of just about everything I've had here.  It's maybe not as well spiced as Cancun on a good night, and the salsa variety isn't as good as Pancho Villa, but when one wants a burrito or some nachos it's a fine choice.  

They do lack tortas, which irks me, but that's a minor quibble when all is said and done.
author: Gustie L.

description:
My man and I live on the other side of the city, but every once in a while, we would brave the horrific Mission parking conditions for a super prawn _____ here! (Fill in blank with burrito, quesadilla, taco, etc) It comes with all the typical fixings and juicy, grilled prawns. We really should try the other items, but we couldn't really bring ourselves to not eat the prawns. :P

Unless you're a big fan of grease, I'd stay away from the tostada because the tortilla is HEAVILY deep fried. I thought their nachos were a little too heavy on the cheese also.

Another great thing about this place is that it's pretty clean as far as taquerias go. It's also pretty crowded and noisy though if you go at peak times.
author: Bekki J.

description:
Famous La Corneta-- go to get stuffed and all at low low prices.  I take my enchilada dish home and i make two meals out of it.  They have good mole-- not the best--but really good mole.  Mole is my favourite food of all time; i am still searching for the best and I might have to trek to Oaxaca.  

Buen Provecho!
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
Clean.

Clean.

Clean.

Brightly colored.

Yum.

A good super veggie, but I still think pancho villa's might be a little bit better.
author: Angela H.

description:
If you need your taqueria to be really clean, or you want to take your parents to get a burrito in the Mission without alarming them, this is the place to go. It's a swell place to linger over your food. It's huge, well-lit, and tiled. The people who work here don't look demoralized or harangued.

I recommend the quesadillas; if you like camarones (shrimps), theirs are divine, esp. in the quesadilla. They grill them to this partly crispy perfection in garlic butter. The veggies are crisp, too; if you get the super, tell them easy on the sour cream. 

However, their burritos are lackluster. You can throw a dart at a map of the Mission and find a better burrito. They're fine, but not worth going out of your way for. For burritos, I'd rather get a great burrito from a filthy and slightly scary joint that feels like a way station in purgatorio (i.e., el Farolito or Cancun on 19th and Mission). If you want a truly magnificent upscale burrito, go to Papalote instead. They have two kinds of shrimps.
author: Tarin T.

description:
so yesterday after our belly dance class ended in the mission, we looked for a place to eat. there were taquerias on EVERY corner, so it was hard to decide on a place. we first passed on la corneta after seeing a sign on the door saying "HOMOCIDE INFORMATION NEEDED, CALL POLICE." -we're like "shit, i don't wanna get shot just tryna get a burrito!" so we kept walking.... then 5 minutes later nothing else looked good so we turned around and went into la corneta, for some reason.

i was looking on the menu at the burritos and saw they had baby burritos, and super baby burritos..

me: oh shit, they have "baby burritos"! i wonder what the difference between that and a "super baby burrito" is??
